Well it's been a little over a month and a half (including a vacation hiatus) and we've reached the end of the Quentin Tarantino/Robert Rodriguez Expletive Dleted project. It's been a hell of a ride. We're ending this with Robert Rodriguez' return to the Spy Kid franchise.

What I love about Robert Rodriguez when it comes to kiddie movies is that he really does have a Peter Pan complex himself. He's a Toys R Us kid who doesn't wanna grow up. He may not be able to nail the appeals-to-the-adults aspect that makes the best kid flicks, but he's got the juvenile mentality down pretty \m/ well. 

Spy Kids 4 checks in with our original kids and introduces a new spy family. The details of the story are incredibly cheesey and implausible, but the fun vibe is still there. New gadets, new spies, new baddies. Besides bringing back Alexa Vega and Darryl Sabarra, we're adding in Jessica Alba, Joel McHale, and Jeremy Piven. If you can overlook the glaring plotholes and dumb dialogue, it's a great ride. It just takes a lot of effort and the proper mindset to do so.

So yeah, I'd have liked to end this project on a better note, but you can't win 'em all. We've got Django Unchained to look forward to later this year from Tarantino and Rodriguez' Machete Kills shouldnt be too far behind. I'm already scheming my next project, so look for that in October. Until then, I'll just be spending all my time at the movie theater. Yay!

The 4th Spy Kids installment came unexpectedly, and with moderate commercial success. The Cortez family from the previous movies has been pushed aside for a new cast of actors in a new spy family, the Cortez-Wilsons. The original kids Carmen and Juni do appear in this installment, but act as supporting characters for the new cast. Even their potential to trigger nostalgia for older Spy Kids fans, who watched the originals when they were young enough to enjoy them (like me), isn't enough to save the weak jokes and nonsensical plot here.

The storyline in Spy Kid 4 is disjointed and unoriginal, and ultimately, makes absolutely no sense. The screenwriters probably spent little time attempting to develop a somewhat cohesive plot to follow. The acting is wooden and stiff, as is the misplaced dialogue. The weak attempts at humor are depressing, and, at times, cringe-inducing.

The first two Spy Kids films were far from perfect, but at least the absurd ideas made for funny results and repeated viewings. When you're making ridiculous fantasy spy films for a young audience, you need to be creative and take some risks. Things like the Thumb-Thumbs, fantastical creatures on the Lost Island, and a four-headed David Shaloub made the original films entertaining.

The simple charm and connection between family members also made the originals work. How they interact, argue as families do, and ultimately band together to save the day was fun to see. But any hint of those feelings in this installment is lost by the lack of effort by all involved with 4. I tried, but failed, to find a single good thing in this movie. If you want a simple adventure spy movie for the whole family, maybe not the best one, but at something with a sense of fun and creativity, then stick with the first two Spy Kids, because this is just sad and unnecessary.

The Spy Kids films are some of my favorite guilty pleasures, and I find they often have material for both kids and adults to enjoy. Itâ(TM)s no surprise that this flick was so high on my list of most anticipated films of 2011, and even with the first trailer premiere I was still hopeful. Gone is the magic of the first three films, centering on a completely different family and only occasionally dropping hints about the rest of the franchise. This movie fails because the characters we have grown to love over the years, Carmen and Juny, are in the movie for all of about ten minutes. The new kids (and cast) just really donâ(TM)t have what it takes, nor does the incredibly terrible script littered with plot holes.

Spy Kids: All the Time in the World is a remarkable film. And not because it's particularly any good. It's a remarkable film because it makes Spy Kids 3D: Game Over look like Citizen Kane. It makes the worst film in the Spy Kids series be the second worst film in the Spy Kids series. That's how completely awful All the Time in the World is.

So the very first scene has Jeremy Piven getting chased by a nine month pregnant Jessica Alba....NINE MONTHS. There is no possible way that a spy agency would ever allow a NINE MONTH PREGNANT WOMAN into the field to do a job. There's NO WAY. Ever heard of a little thing called MATERNITY LEAVE? Oh wait, it's a kids movie and she's doing a bit that's funny to kids, right... But just because it's a kids movie does not mean that the humor has to be stupid. In fact kids should be offended by how dumb the humor is. That opening scene alone is entirely indicative of how utterly offensive this movie is.

The gaps in common sense and logic are abundant to the point of absurdity. The people in this movie are so stupid, it's any wonder they all haven't died already from sheer unconscionable stupidity. And while we're on the subject of death, the new Spy Kids are without a doubt some of the most obnoxious children I've ever seen in a movie (the girl especially). I kept hoping that they'd both horribly die at some point, but alas that was just wishful thinking on my part. I kept hoping and praying that they'd suffer and die from some horribly gruesome and sadistic series of Saw-like traps. Too bad that never happened...but a guy can dream can't he?

Not only are they supremely obnoxious and irritating as characters, but they're also some of the worst child actors I've ever seen. Should I cut them some slack? Not at all. Just because they're kids does not excuse them from being atrocious actors. Want good child actors? See Natalie Portman in Leon: The Professional, Saoirse Ronan in Atonement or Chloe Grace Moretz in  500 Days of Summer or Kick-Ass. Even the original Spy Kids Daryl Sabara and Alexa Vega were better in their first movie than these kids.

Sadly, the adult actors don't really fare that much better. Jessica Alba still looks great as always, even when delivering some of worst lines of dialogue this side of the stratosphere. It makes me die on the inside to see Joel McHale in this movie. JEFF WHAT ARE YOU DOING IN THIS MOVIE? YOU ARE JEFF WINGER FROM COMMUNITY! YOU BELONG AT GREENDALE. YOU ARE WITTY SARCASTIC JEFF, NOT AWKWARD AND UNFUNNY DAD WILBUR WILSON. GET THAT. Jeremy Piven I liked you so much better when you were Ari Gold in Entourage. And Ricky Gervais as the attack dog? No...just...no...

Now I'll admit that I liked that Robert Rodriguez brought back the original Spy Kids for the film, if only to remind me of how much better the first and to a lesser extent the second and third films are to this utter abysmal abomination of a fourth movie. Those were the days...

And I'm sure I'd be remisced if I neglected to mention some of the completely revolting puns and lines of dialogue in this movie regarding time. Thing is I love puns. Just not ones that small children who don't know what's good for them can understand. Puns like "Clocked you", "Time's up" or "This time we better stop the Time Keeper from stopping time.." Really? Really? There's a special rung in Hell reserved just for bad movies like this. Thanks for ruining my childhood...

But the biggest offense this movie has to offer is the very fact that it's another film in a long line of garbage that has kept Robert Rodriguez from making the one movie that he actually does need to make which will most certainly save his career: Sin City 2.
So bad that it cannot be described in words. I want the director, cast and crew of this movie to get run over. Repeatedly.
what the hell... it's ridiculous... not even funny...

rt_summary: Marissa Cortez Wilson (Jessica Alba) is a retired spy who keeps that identity hidden from her clueless husband and whip-smart twin stepchildren, Rebecca (Rowan Blanchard) and Cecil (Mason Cook). However, when a villain called Timekeeper (Jeremy Piven) threatens to conquer the world, Marissa springs back into action as head of the OSS, home of the now-defunct Spy Kids Division. With help from some cool gadgets and two former spy kids, Rebecca and Cecil join the fight to save Earth.
meta_summary: On the surface, Marissa Cortez Wilson has it all...married to a famous spy hunting television reporter, a new baby and intelligent twin step kids.  But in reality, trying to mother Rebecca and Cecil, who clearly don’t want her around, is her toughest challenge yet. With Armageddon quickly approaching, Rebecca and Cecil are thrust into action when they learn their boring stepmom was once a top agent and now the world’s most competitive ten year olds are forced to put their bickering aside and rely on their wits.
